title: Synthetic Recap
body:
DALLAS – History arrived at Reunion Arena on a blistering night in 1998, wearing the number 13 for the Dallas Mavericks. In a virtuoso performance for the ages, Michael Finley detonated for a career-high 42 points, single-handedly carrying his team to a 107-98 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics.

From the opening tip, it was clear Finley was operating on a different plane. He attacked the rim with ferocity and connected from mid-range with a cool efficiency, slicing through a Sonics defense that had no answer. While Seattle’s Gary Payton (24 points) and Vinny Askew (20 points) fought valiantly to keep pace, their efforts were merely background noise to the Finley symphony.

The game remained tight, a back-and-forth struggle defined by Finley’s relentless scoring. Every time the Sonics threatened to build momentum, Finley had a response—a silky jumper, a powerful drive, a play that silenced the threat and energized the home crowd. He was not merely scoring; he was controlling the very tempo of the contest, a one-man offense willing his team across the finish line.

Finley’s supporting cast provided just enough muscle, with A.C. Green securing a game-high 13 rebounds to control the glass. But this night belonged to one man. When the final horn sounded on his 42-point masterpiece, the result was secondary. The story was the historic, dominant force of Michael Finley, a performance etched forever in Mavericks lore.
